issue.title: Ability to scoop up events that reach the tail of the ChannelPipeline

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation

There is currently no way to enforce the position of a handler in a ChannelPipeline and assume you wanted to write something like a custom Channel type that acts as a proxy between two other Channels.

ProxyChannel(Channel client, Channel server) {
  client calls write(msg) -> server.write(msg)
  client calls flush() -> server.flush()
  server calls fireChannelRead(msg) -> client.write(msg)
  server calls fireChannelReadComplete() -> client.flush()
}

In order to make it work reliably one needs to be able to scoop up the various events at the head and tail of the pipeline. The head side of the pipeline is covered by Unsafe and it's also relatively safe to count on the user to not use the addFirst() method to manipulate the pipeline. The tail side is always at a risk of getting broken because addLast() is the goto method to add handlers.

Modifications

Adding a few extra methods to DefaultChannelPipeline that expose some of the events that reach the pipeline's TailContext.

Result

Fixes #7484

issue.title: Netty SubChannelHandler

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Similar to #7484, I have a requirement to provide a Channel implementation for users to add their own handlers to, but I have my own handlers that need to retain their original positions in the overall data flow.

I chose to approach this by adding a SubChannelHandler to the primary ChannelPipeline, that contains a custom Channel implementation (SubChannel) that simply forwards traffic back on to the parent Channel when it reaches the head or tail of the SubChannel. In this way, users can add their handlers to the SubChannel in any way they choose (addLast, addFirst, etc), without the possibility of displacing my own handlers in the parent Channel.

This issue is primarily to ask whether there is any interest in this as a generic feature in Netty, and if I should submit a PR for it? 

It is currently implemented against the latest Netty 4.1 codebase.

issue.title: Any ways to supply custom ChanelPipeline?

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Hey Netty team,

Started to extend the `DefaultChannelPipeline` and found out that it is not possible due to: 
- `AbsractChannel` relies on `DefaultChannelPipeline` class rather than `ChannelPipeline` interface
- `DefaultChannelPipeline` is 'effectively final' (all interface methods are implemented as `final`)

I would suggest either one of the following options: 
1. Change `AbstractChannel` to depend on `ChannelPipeline` instead of `DefaultChannelPipeline` (the same as 'Idea 1' in #7484)
I've found just 2 usages of `DefaultChannelPipeline` specific methods: `estimatorHandle()` and `invokeHandlerAddedIfNeeded()` which can be pulled-up to the interface (with maybe slight redesign)
2. Relax `DefaultChannelPipeline` and remove final modifiers
3. At least add pipeline modification callbacks (like handlerAdded/Removed) to the `DefaultChannelPipeline`

Background use case: https://github.com/libp2p/jvm-libp2p/issues/39
Closely relates to #7484
